ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed more knowledge of the Japanese language, and culture, and have become closer to fluency.
Better knowledge of speaking, writing, and reading Japanese.
My Japanese (especially my grammar) got much stronger, and I feel more comfortable speaking and understanding Japanese.
I learned a great amount of Japanese grammar, vocabulary, and kanji characters. I developed better conversational skills in Japanese.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course does force you to learn at a high pace, and it is paired with mostly daily assignments (whether or not that's a strength or a weakness is up to you).

Strengths: - Good for Japanese Comprehension and practice. - emphasis on Japanese Speech and formalities

Weakness: - workload - instructor

Strengths: large number of skills learned, lots of opportunities for participation, learning about Japanese culture 
Weaknesses: assignments can take a long time to be graded, every worksheet had to be printed by students

Strengths: I think the class time was spent very well, combining speaking and grammar practice with cultural learning. I also thought the tests were very fair.
Weaknesses: I would have liked more feedback on our oral exams, because I was left not knowing what speaking skills I needed to work on the most.
It was very helpful to thoroughly go over the new grammar in class and practice it right afterward.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think this course is fine for people that want to learn Japanese. The pace is the same as previous levels and it does introduce lots of new topics and provide lots of opportunity to practice. It is unfortunate, however, that as of right now only one professor teaches all sections of L3.

I would recommend it only if you need it for a distributional requirement. There is a lot of work, and many of my peers, and I concur, that the workload is much higher in this course than in previous or later Japanese studies and the payoff is minimal.
Yes, if you would like to improve your Japanese in a fast-paced and immersive atmosphere then take this class. It's also a great way to meet other people who also enjoy learning Japanese.
Yes! For anyone looking to improve their Japanese, the class did a great job.
